Recipe.title: Wild Blackberry Jam
Recipe.Description: In Washington, we have wild blackberries growing everywhere. One year, we decided to make jam, and it turned out wonderful! This recipe is pretty basic, but it is the one we use.

section.title: Making Mashed Berries
section.instruction: Let berries soak in a large bowl, and pick out grass, leaves, etc. that floats to the top.
Drain, then rinse berries in a strainer or colander.
Mash berries, using a potato masher or something similar.

section.title: Jam
section.instruction: Put Mashed Wild Blackberries into a large pot, add Lemon Juice and mix well.
Bring berry mixture to a boil.
In a separate bowl, mix Sugar and Pectin.
When berry mixture is boiling, slowly mix in Sugar/Pectin mixture and stir until well dissolved.
Bring mixture to a boil again, and boil for 1 minute, then remove from heat immediately.
Follow instructions in the Bath Canning: How-To section.

Notes.note:
Cooking time in Bath Canner:
Altitude Time
Below 1000 feet 5 minutes
1000-6000 feet 10 minutes
Above 6000 feet 15 minutes
If you let the jam boil too long, it will not "set" and you end up with runny syrup instead of jam.
We do not recommend using liquid pectin. When we do, we have had problems getting it to set.
Instead of mashing fruit, you can place fruit in a blender and blend it for a few seconds until it is just barely liquefied.
The Lemon Juice raises the acidity level of the jam so it will not spoil when stored.
If you have a big enough pot, there is no reason that you can't double the recipe.

Modifications.modification: If you are not going to can the Jam, the Lemon Juice can be omitted.
